We assess human rights, including modern slavery risks, in our operations through both social and environmental impact assessments and risk-based due diligence. We complete community social baseline studies and impact assessments at each process, including the identification and evaluation of human rights risks, using an approach aligned with the UN Guiding Principles.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column7: Our Ethics and Compliance Framework assesses and monitors the development and implementation of adequate policies, standards and controls to ensure we operate legally, responsibly and with integrity across all operations. Key focus areas include Code of Conduct, anti-bribery and corruption, fraud, sanctions, conflicts of interest, data protection, privacy, and Speak Out.\t

Respecting the environment is a critical pillar in our sustainability approach. NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs Environmental Policy is supported by several performance standards that guide NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs risk-based approach to management of water stewardship, land use and disturbance, biodiversity, waste rock and tailings management, hazardous waste and closure planning.

Employees and contractors: Employee briefings, intranet, email, newsletters, social events, notice boards, departmental site and toolbox meetings, performance reviews, town hall meetings, and Organisational Health surveys.
Local Communities: Community Relations team visits, resident and community meetings, site visits/tours, communication and feedback forums, dedicated communication contacts, environmental and social impacts complaints and grievance mechanisms, sponsorships and partnerships, collaborative agreements, media engagement on local initiatives, community newsletters, factsheets, and websites & social media.
Shareholders: Annual Reports, Annual General Meeting, half-yearly financial reporting, quarterly production and exploration reports, website and email, investor briefings, investor days, meetings, conference calls, market announcements, conferences and social media.
Government and regulators: Department meetings, regular briefings by telephone and email, website and social media publications.
Suppliers: Collaborative guidelines, out-to-market approaches, meetings, contractual agreements and questionnaires.
Customers: Market tenders, meetings, reports, conference engagement, and site visits.
Industry: Industry forums, conference engagement, working groups and committees, email, and internet portals.

Newcrest manages the annual assessment process and engages an independent external specialist to qualify for the function every second year. In FY23, weÃÂ undertook the following: Desktop review of internal materials, Review of exterior materials, including industry trends and best practices, Peer analysis and materiality benchmarking, Broad internal and external stakeholder survey, including employees across varyingÃÂ levels, locations and functions, suppliers, customers, industry associations, academia, NGOs and technical experts. This process provided a view of NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs material topics, which NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs Executive Committee and Board confirmed.

The material sustainability topics most important to our stakeholders and business are identified through the materiality determination process. The GRI Standards and AccountabilityÃ¢ÂÂs Five-Part Materiality Test involves an independent assessment of a range of directly relevant sources, including internal policy, risk and strategy documents, media, peer and industry publications, and benchmarking, as well as representative internal and external key stakeholder interviews. Newcrest manages the annual assessment process and engages an external specialist to qualify the function every second year (completed in FY22).

Newcrest's Sustainability Data Centre is being developed across multiple phases. Phase 1 of the project focused on data extraction from existing Newcrest systems and was delivered in FY22. Phase 2 of the project concentrated on energy and emissions data and was completed in FY23.

column6: Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
column7: Ratios of standard entry-level wages compared to the local minimum wage are not captured by gender. Newcrest defines entry-level wages by job classification, not by gender. Irrespective of the gender, the employee in a position is paid the same.

column6: Proportion of senior management hired from the local community
column7: In the Company, there are 91% of Senior Management. In Brucejack, there are 100% of Senior Management; in Cadia, there are 100% of Senior Management; in Lihir, there are 22% of Senior Management; in Red Chris, there are 93% of Senior Management; in Telfer, there are 100% of Senior Management, and in Corporate Offices, there are 99% of Senior Management.

column13: Together with Ngurra Kujungka, our Telfer Operation was recognised for delivering community-driven recreation programs for the Martu people of the Western Desert region. column8: Three-Year Social Performance Continuous Improvement Plan
column13: The three-year Social Performance Continuous Improvement Plan progressed, including a revised governance suite including Group Social Performance Standards, Procedures, Guidelines, and templates. Mapping of social performance competencies and career pathways. Introduction of mandatory external training and certification for social performance practitioners. Investment in NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs social performance management system to increase activity and improve functionality
column20: Social Performance Continuous Improvement Plan, External Training, Performance Management System

column13: All Newcrest operating sites maintain a grievance management system for community members and employees tailored to the local context. Social Performance practitioners are trained in using this system, and feedback is incorporated into ongoing improvement measures. When there is a grievance or dispute, we engage in constructive dialogue, seeking and providing respectful feedback and responding promptly.
column20: Grievance Management System, Local Context, Constructive Dialogue

column13: In FY23, we updated our Procurement Standard, outlining our continued intention to procure goods and services from suppliers who uphold our sustainability expectations. In addition to commercial, safety and operational requirements, we have incorporated environmental and social performance criteria into sourcing requirements and tender evaluations. We seek to identify opportunities to enable access for local enterprises, small businesses, and First Nations suppliers to participate in procurement and contracting opportunities.

Newcrest provided direct and indirect contributions to operating jurisdictions through taxes, royalties and other charges and the economic activity, such as local employment generated by our actions. In addition, we made voluntary contributions to community development and assistance programs to strengthen community resilience.
column20: Direct and Indirect Contributions, Taxes, Royalties, Voluntary Contributions
